Alright dumbfuck, let's do a simple piece of math. Eh?

1 teacher gets sick. That teacher interacts with 5 other teachers who each interact with 2-3 other adults. how many are infected?

That teacher teaches 5 classes of 30 students a piece. How many people are infected?

Those 150 students go home to 3 person households (mother, father, child). How many are infected?

Coronavirus has a 2 week incubation period where it's typically asymptomatic while still being highly infectious. Meaning if a teacher is showing symptoms, how many people have been exposed for up to 2 weeks from a single teacher?

If the teacher has to go on sick leave, is her sick leave covered? 

Now consider the fact that prolonged exposure beats high resistance far more often than not.

WASHINGTON, D.C. (The Borowitz Report)—Amid the debate over reopening the nation’s schools, a new poll shows that an overwhelming majority of Americans would like Donald J. Trump to go back to school in the fall.  Due to social-distancing requirements, those surveyed agreed that there should be limits on class size when Trump returns to school, but that his class should be large enough to accommodate other education-starved students such as Jared Kushner, Rand Paul, and Betsy DeVos. 
 
Although Americans acknowledge that the logistics of sending Trump back to school could be complicated and expensive, the cost of his continuing lack of education is far greater, the poll indicates.  Americans were split on which school subjects they would like to see Trump focus on most when he returns to the classroom.  Science and math received the strongest support, but a substantial number of respondents also favored history, geography, and English.  Finally, if Trump is ordered back to school in the fall, a vast majority of respondents urged that steps be taken to insure that he does not send someone else in his place.

@Wise One Thank you for sharing your point of view. I bring up other countries only to show how others have more successfully dealt with certain social issues. I understand that their history and culture and implementation varies from the US, but I point to them as examples of of where it works (imperfectly of course, but where there is a better quality of life for more of their citizens as a result). While I have no doubt that there are people who take advantage of social programs, they cost the US a fraction of the cost of rich people and corporations taking advantage of tax loop holes, bail outs, or regulations. But I'm glad we agree on that one, and am happy you will support and press for policies that address that. 

In terms of tackling poverty, you're right that it is incredibly complicated and attempts were made in the past that were either ineffective, short-lived, or short-sighted. You seem like a thoughtful person, so I'm certain you're beyond the 'poor people are just lazy' argument, but that you don't see social programs as helping them move beyond dependency. The question I start with is "Why are people poor?"

...I'm not an expert, but here's just one example: I can see that the minimum wage is so low here that when faced with the choice of working two jobs to feed my kids and pay for child care, or accepting government money to stay home and take care of my own kids, what do you think I'm doing to do? The solution to this seems to be to increase the minimum wage. Although this might affect the bottom line of corporations (and I'm not ignoring the impact on small businesses either) but eventually if raised over the course of a few years, we will adjust. 

Maybe people are poor because of mental health issues, or addictions. If that is the case, giving them blank checks isn't really helping them either. So maybe the solution is investing that money into better health programs. 

Recognizing that we also have an economic system that relies on having a certain percentage of the population unemployed, is also important. If unemployment gets too low, we have inflation issues so we will never have 0% unemployment. Knowing that, what should we do with these people? 

I have a lot more questions than answers, and I'm glad you're willing to talk with me about this. I think there are lot intelligent people working on these issues, and many solutions out there. I also think there are many people who benefit from you believing that poor people are the problem, and if we just stopped supporting them your life would be better. My instincts are to look up at the rich and powerful, the ones benefiting most from the status quo vs. down at the vulnerable and poor when I'm searching for solutions. But mostly I ask a lot of questions. :) Including to people like you who might have different politically leanings.

About a month into the Covid shutdown and shelter in – my city in California was one of the first – I started thinking that something just wasn’t right. I started researching and came across a couple of videos posted by the two doctors from Bakersfield who had a different take on the virus. I just hope more and more people will seek out the truth, open up their minds, and stop being mind controlled by the evil that has taken over our country.

@Johnny C "inform us on Devos' successful policies"

Well, she did claw back the Obama DOE OCR's overreach regarding sexual misconduct on campus. She revoked the rule banning cross examination of accusers, and barring the accused from legal counsel. And she has mandated that the accused be permitted to present evidence in his defence (something that was not happening, and in many cases led to successful lawsuits by disciplined students).

While she didn't tell schools to up the burden of proof from "more likely than not" to "clear and convincing evidence", she told them they need to pick a standard and use it for all misconduct adjudications (not just sexual, and not just when the accused is a student). And she revoked the common practice of schools adjudicating alleged sexual misconduct that occurs off campus, or involves an accuser who is not affiliated with the school, because Title IX is about what happens to students *at school,* not what happens elsewhere to non-students.

In order to develop these policies, she did not just speak to victim advocacy groups, but to groups representing the interests of due process for accused students and groups dedicated to individual rights in education. 

And it might interest you to know that false and/or exaggerated accusations of campus sexual misconduct disproportionately target minority students.

@Tina Rio The CDC is considering removing the "epidemic" designation for COVID19, because as they get more of an idea as to how many people have it and _have had_ it, the overall infection fatality rate is looking to be comparable to a severe flu. Their current estimate is 0.26%, and that estimate could get smaller the more data they gather.

If and when they do that, it will be more difficult for politicians to justify lockdowns and other measures. 

Incidentally, it's not just US politicians and experts who are coof-mad. One expert on CBC radio yesterday (Canada) trotted out the idea of reinfection as an argument against making antibody tests widely available. The problem, she insisted, is that "we don't yet know" whether antibodies confer protection against reinfection. Therefore, if people test positive for antibodies they may erroneously believe they're safe and engage in behaviors that expose them to reinfection. 

This is stupid beyond words. She's arguing that we don't know if COVID is an exception to the general rule of viruses, so we should assume it is an exception. Worse still, if it IS an exception to the rule, a vaccine won't be possible, because vaccines rely on the "antibodies confer protection" concept. And to be frank, the successful use of convalescent blood plasma to treat COVID patients strongly suggests that antibodies do provide protection.

It's as if they just do not want to admit that COVID19 may not be as dangerous as previously thought.
